Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Where is it, lady -- where've you got it?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I don't know -- I don't know! I don't --

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: I want it -- give it to me -- it's mine!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Peter -- ! Peter -- !

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: A man -- he tried to kill me!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Peter! Where are you?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Peter -- are you all right?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I think I sprained my pride.  Where'd he go?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Out of the window, I guess -- I didn't see him.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Lock the door and the window -- and don't let anyone in except me. I'll be back in a minute.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Be careful, Peter.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You took the words right out of my mouth.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: That was a dumb move, Herman -- a dumb move.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: And then some. If you'd only told us you was goin' to her room we could've kept 'em busy --

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: -- but sneakin' in there on your own that-a-way, why, man, you was bound to get yore tokus kicked. I mean, what'd you think he'd do -- walk up 'n' shake you by that hand o' yores?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I didn't hurt you, did I?

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: Never mind that -- did you get the money?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: How could I with the three Marx Brothers breathing down my neck? You said you'd let me handle it alone -- ! The girl trusts me. If she's got it, I'll find out about it. But you've got to leave me alone.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: We took all the chances. The money belongs to us, not him!

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Don't be un-neighborly-like, Herman -- don't forget he done us a little ol' favor.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Yeah? What's that?

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: He took care of Charlie for us.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: We appreciate it, really we do.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: But who asked him? Three shares are enough -- I'd say he's out!

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: A third of nothing is nothing, Herman. Make up your minds -- she's waiting for me.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: I don't see how another twenty-four hours could hurt.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Shoot no, not after all these years.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Then he gets it out of your share, not mine! Not mine!

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: I suggest you get about your business -- nothing soothes Herman like success.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: That's right -- it's like ticklin' a alligator's belly.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Who's got the room next to hers?

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Me. How come?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Get another one, will you? I'm going to need it.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: If you do find the money -- you won't forget t' tell us about it, will you, fella?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Don't worry.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Oh, I ain't worryin' -- but see this pudgy little fella here?  He worries -- an' he's even meaner'n I am.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: There was no trace of him. All right, Reggie -- suppose you tell me what this is all about.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: There are three men -- he's one of them -- they think I have something that belongs to them.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: A quarter of a million dollars.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: That's all.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: No, it isn't -- where's the money?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I don't know.  Those men killed Charles to get it. But he must not have had it with him on the train.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: So they think he left it with you.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But he didn't! I've looked everywhere --  Those men going to kill me.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: No, they won't -- I won't let them.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Please help me, Peter -- you're the only one I can trust.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Of course I'll help -- I told you I would, didn't I? Come on now --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm so hungry I could faint.  I've -- I've gotten your suit all wet.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: That's all right -- it's a drip-dry.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Peter, you've got to promise me something. Promise you'll never lie the way Charles did. Why do people have to tell lies?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Usually it's because they want something -- and they're afraid the truth won't get it for them.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Do you tell lies?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Mrs. Lampert? -- it's me -- the man who was in your room a few minutes ago --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: The man you had the fight with.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Is Dyle with you?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: The man who hit me, lady -- Dyle -- that's his name. What's wrong -- is he still there?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Yes -- that's right.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: What is it, Reggie -- what's he saying?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Don't trust him -- don't tell him anything. He's after the money.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: What'd he say?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: He -- he said if I didn't give the money, he'll kill me.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I wouldn't take that too seriously.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I believe what he said.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: They're only trying to scare you, that's all.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: How do you know what they're doing?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I don't -- but as long as they think you have the money, or know where it is, or have it without knowing where it is, or don't even know you have it --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You mustn't let what he said bother you. It was only words.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Words can hurt very much.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Go to sleep -- I'll see you in the morning.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Don't put yourself out.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Hey -- I'm on your side. Remember that.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Yes, I'll remember. Good night.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: But if you'll take my advice --  You'll undress in the closet. Oh, and if you need me, just bang on the wall. I'll be next door.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Mr. Bartholomew? -- are you still there?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: I don't know who this Mr. Dyle is, but it's just possible we were wrong about who killed your husband.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You mean he might have -- Mr. Bartholomew, I'm catching the next plane out of here -- I'm not going to sit here and wait for someone to make chopped liver out of me!

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Where are you now -- can you meet me? Do you know Les Halles?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: -- in fifteen minutes. I'll be there.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Reggie -- !

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Taxi -- !

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: N'importe o -- vite! Allez-y!

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Taxi -- ! Taxi -- !

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Follow that taxi.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Comment?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Taxi! Follow!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Je ne comprends rien.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Suivre -- el taxi!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Ah! Oui, Monsieur.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Aux Halles -- vite!

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Incredible, isn't it? Zola called it 'le ventre de Paris' -- the womb of Paris, the belly.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What did you want to see me about, Mr. Bartholomew?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Were you followed?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Yes, but I lost him. I really did it quite brilliantly. I'm beginning to think women make the best spies.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Agents.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: He has a gun, Mr. Bartholomew -- I saw it.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Dyle, or whatever his name is.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: What does your Mr. Dyle look like, Mrs. Lampert?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: He's hardly my Mr. Dyle.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Describe him.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Well -- he's tall -- over six feet -- rather thin -- in good physical shape, I'd say -- dark eyes -- quite handsome, really.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: No, what?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: That's not Carson Dyle.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Carson?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: There's only one Dyle connected with this affair, Mrs. Lampert -- that's Carson.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You mean you've known about him all along? Why didn't you tell me?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: It's enough to make you a vegetarian, isn't it?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: It's just lucky that I'm not hanging next to one of those things right now.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Mr. Bartholomew -- why didn't you tell me you knew about Dyle?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: I didn't see any point. Dyle's dead.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Dead? Mr. Bartholomew -- maybe you'd better tell me what this thing's all about.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: I suppose you're old enough to have heard of World War Two?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Barely, yes.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: In 1944, five members of the O.S.S. -- the military espionage unit -- were ordered behind the German lines for the purpose of delivering $250,000 in gold to the French Underground. The five men --

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Vous dsirez?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: They always do that.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Caf.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Gratine, choucroute garnie, salade de pommes -- et un ballon de rouge.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Mrs. Lampert, I really hadn't planned on spending the entire night here.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Can I at least keep the onion soup?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: La soupe tout simplement.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Go on, please -- five men -- $250,000 -- the French Underground --

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Yes. The five men. They were, of course, your husband, Charles, the three men who showed up at his funeral yesterday, and Carson Dyle. But something went wrong and they were unable to locate their contact. It must have been at that point that they decided to steal the money.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Steal it how?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: By burying it, and then reporting that the Germans had captured it. All they had to do was come back after the war, dig it up and split it five ways -- a quarter of a million dollars with no questions asked.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: May I have a cigarette, please?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I hate these things -- it's like drinking coffee through a veil.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Everything went smoothly enough until after the gold was buried -- then, before they could get out, they were ambushed by a German patrol. A machine gun separated Scobie from his right hand -- and caught Carson Dyle full in the stomach.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: What's wrong with that one?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh. Nothing, I guess. What happened then?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Have you any idea what these things cost over here?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Please go on, Mr. Bartholomew -- what happened then?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Scobie was able to travel, but Carson Dyle was clearly dying, so they --

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: La soupe, c'est pour qui?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Pour moi. Go on, Mr. Bartholomew.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Carson was dying so they were forced to leave him. They finally got back to the base, made their report, and waited for the war to end. Only Charles couldn't wait quite as long as the others. He beat them back to the gold, took everything for himself and disappeared. It's taken Gideon, Tex and Scobie all this time to catch up with him again.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But if they stole all that money -- why can't you arrest them?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: We know what happened from the bits and pieces we were able to paste together -- but we still have no proof.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But what has all this got to do with the C.I.O.?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: C.I.A., Mrs. Lampert. We're an extension of the wartime O.S.S. It was our money and we want it back.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Mr. Bartholomew, but nothing you've told me has changed my mind. I still intend leaving Paris -- tonight.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: I wouldn't advise that, Mrs. Lampert. You'd better consider what happened to your husband when he tried to leave. Those men won't be very far away -- no matter where you go. In fact, I don't even see any point in your changing hotels. Please help us, Mrs. Lampert. Your government is counting on you.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Well, if I'm going to die, I might as well do it for my country.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: That's the spirit.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh, stop it. What do you want me to do?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: We're anxious to know who this man is -- the one calling himself Dyle.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Maybe he really is Dyle. He could still be alive.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: No, Mrs. Lampert.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But no one actually saw him die.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: No, Mrs. Lampert. His death is registered with the War Department in Washington.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh. Then who's this one?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: I don't know -- but I think you'd better find out, don't you?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Me? Why me?

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: You're in an ideal position -- he trusts you.  Besides, you said yourself, women make the best spies.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Agents.

Speaker: tourist
Dialogue: Fraulein --

Speaker: tourist
Dialogue: Fraulein --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What are you doing, following me? Stop it -- we're going to look like a parade.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: How are you? When did you arrive in town? Are you enjoying Paris? It's lovely, isn't it? So many wonderful things to see and do, it makes one's head spin to think of it.

Speaker: tourist
Dialogue: Fraulein --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: If you don't stop following me I'll call the police.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Taxi -- !

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Dyle, please... D - Y - L - E.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Dyle. I remember.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Mr. Dyle -- nothing today.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Thanks -- see you soon.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Good morning, Mr. Dyle.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Reggie?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: It's the only name I've got. How about you?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: No cat and mouse -- you've got me. What do you want to know?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Why you lied to me.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: I had to -- for all I knew you could have been in on the whole thing.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Well, you know now, so please tell me who you are.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: But you know my name -- it's Dyle.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Carson Dyle is dead.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Yes, he is. He was my brother.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Your --

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: The army thinks he was killed in action by the Germans, but I think they did it -- Tex, Gideon and Scobie -- and your husband -- because he wouldn't go along with their scheme to steal the gold. I think he threatened to turn them in and they killed him. I'm trying to prove it. They think I'm working with them. But I'm not, and that's the truth. I'm on your side, Reggie -- please believe that.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: How can I? You lied to me -- the way Charles did -- and after promising you wouldn't. Oh, I want to believe you, Peter... oh, but I can't call you that anymore, can I? It will take me a while to get used to your new name -- which I don't even know yet. What is it?  Hello -- ?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: If you do anything funny, or try to talk to anyone, I'll kill you, Dyle -- here and now. Okay?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: You'll wreck your raincoat.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Next car, please.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Okay -- turn around.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: What now?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: We wait -- with our mouths shut.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: How long do you intend -- ?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: I said with the mouth shut.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Sorry about that.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Okay -- up there.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Do I knock or something?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Open it.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Keep going.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: The view had better be worth it.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Very pretty. Now what?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: I'll give you a chance, Dyle -- which is more than you'd give me. Where's the money?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Is that why you dragged me all the way up here -- to ask me that? She has it -- you know that.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: And I say maybe you both have it! One more time, Dyle -- where is it?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Supposing I did have it -- which I don't -- do you really think I'd hand it over?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: You're out, Dyle -- right now!

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Step back.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Back where?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: That's the idea.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Herman?

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: How are you doing?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: If you get bored, try writing 'Love thy neighbor' a hundred times on the side of the building.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: I didn't do it.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: The next time madame forgets her key, there is another one at the desk.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Is that you?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Didn't anyone ever tell you it's impolite to --  What happened?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: I met a man with sharp nails.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Scobie?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: I left him hanging around the American Express.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Come on -- I've got something that stings like crazy.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Take off your shirt and lie down.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Listen -- all I really want is an estimate.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: It's not so bad. You may not be able to lie on your back for a few days -- but, then, you can lie from any position, can't you?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Does it hurt?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Haven't you got a bullet I can bite?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Are you really Carson Dyle's brother?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Would you like to see my passport?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Your passport! What kind of a proof is that?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Would you like to see where I was tattooed?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Okay, I'll drive you around there some day.  Ouch!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Ha ha. You could at least tell me what your first name is these days.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Alexander.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Is there a Mrs. Dyle?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Yes, but we're divorced.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I thought that was Peter Joshua.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: I'm no easier to live with than he was.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: There -- you're a new man.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: I'm sorry I couldn't tell you the truth, but I had to find out your part in all this.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Alex -- how can you tell if someone is lying or not?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: You can't.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: There must be some way.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: There's an old riddle about two tribes of Indians -- the Whitefeet always tell the truth and the Blackfeet always lie. So one day you meet an Indian, you ask him if he's a truthful Whitefoot or a lying Blackfoot? He tells you he's a truthful Whitefoot, but which one is he?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Why couldn't you just look at his feet?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Because he's wearing moccasins.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh. Well, then he's a truthful Whitefoot, of course.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Why not a lying Blackfoot?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Which one are you?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Whitefoot, of course.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Come here.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I hope it turns out you're a Whitefoot, Alex -- I could be very happy hanging around the tepee.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Reggie -- listen to me --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh-oh -- here it comes. The fatherly talk. You forget I'm already a widow.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: So was Juliet -- at fifteen.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm not fifteen.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Well, there's your trouble right there -- you're too old for me.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Why can't you be serious?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: There, you said it.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Said what?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Serious. When a man gets to be my age that's the last word he ever wants to hear. I don't want to be serious -- and I especially don't want you to be.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Okay -- I'll tell you what -- we'll just sit around all day long being frivolous -- how about that?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Now please, Reggie -- cut it out.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Cutting it out.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Who told you to do that?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You did.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: But I'm not through complaining yet.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Now please, Reggie -- cut it out.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I think I love you, Alex --

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: The phone's ringing --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Whoever it is won't give up -- and neither will I.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Sorry -- I was just -- uh -- nibbling on something.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Miz Lampert, my buddies 'n me, we'd oblige it mighty highly if you could mosey on across the hall 'n chew the fat with us for a spell.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Can you give me one good reason why I should?

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. A little one -- 'bout seven or eight years old. Th' little tyke keeps callin' you his Aunt Reggie -- ain't that cute?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: They've got Jean-Louis!

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: That sounds like their problem.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'll be right there.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: We'll be waitin' in room forty-seven, Miz Lampert -- so you just wiggle on over.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What day is it?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Tuesday.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Lord, I forgot all about it -- Sylvie works late Tuesday nights -- she always leaves him with me. They wouldn't do anything to a little boy, would they?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: I don't know -- it depends on whether or not they've already eaten.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Hey, Tex -- move the kid to the other knee or something, will you? My leg's going to sleep.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Upsy-daisy.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Sure am.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Right here -- see?

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: Will you put that thing away!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Jean-Louis!

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Howdy, Miz Lampert.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Who invited you?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Hello, Herman, it was a happy landing, I see.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'd better call Sylvie -- she must be frantic.

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: I'm afraid that will have to wait, Mrs. Lampert.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But his mother --

Speaker: gideon
Dialogue: She isn't going to be anybody's mother unless you answer some questions.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: This ain't no game, Miz Lampert.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: We want that money -- now!

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Be quiet, all of you!

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: And stop threatening that boy. He doesn't have the money. Mrs. Lampert doesn't either.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Then who does?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: I don't know, Herman -- maybe you do.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Or you --

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Slowly. Suppose one of you found Charles here in Paris, followed him, cornered him on the train, threw him out the window and took the money.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: That's a crock! If one of us did that he wouldn't hang around here waiting for the other two to wise up.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: But he'd have to. If he left he'd be admitting his guilt -- and the others would know what happened. Whoever it is has to wait here, pretending to look for the money, waiting for the rest of us to give up and go home. That's when he'll be safe and not a minute before.

Dialogue: Up till now we always figured she had the money -- but you know so much about it, maybe you've got it.

Dialogue: Then what am I doing here? You didn't know anything about me -- I'm the only one who could have taken it and kept right on going.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: It's all right with us --

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: What are we wastin' time for? Let's go.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: And while we're waiting, we might as well go through yours.

Speaker: scobie
Dialogue: Not my room!

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: What's wrong, Herman -- have you got something to hide?  Then I take it there are no objections.

Dialogue: We'd better exchange keys. Here's mine.

Dialogue: I'll take that.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Mine's in the door. Ariva durchy, y'all.

Dialogue: Come on -- let's get busy. Who gets your vote?

Dialogue: Scobie -- he's the one that objected.

Dialogue: He's all yours. I'll do Tex and Gideon. Take Jean-Louis with you -- and make sure you bolt the door from inside.

Dialogue: Viens, Jean-Louis -- we're going to have a treasure hunt.

Dialogue: What should we give him?

Dialogue: Tex?

Dialogue: What's that?

Dialogue: Mebbe we'd better call Herman.

Dialogue: And if it is?

Dialogue: Why bother him?

Dialogue: No. The police have kindly provided us with a list.

Dialogue: Meaning what?

Dialogue: Swell -- only this man doesn't have a garden.

Dialogue: Voil what?

Dialogue: No.

Dialogue: What do I have to do to satisfy you -- become the next victim?

Dialogue: It's a start, anyway.

Dialogue: What do you mean?

Dialogue: You mean, you're a thief?

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Well, it isn't exactly the term I'd have chosen, but I suppose it captures the spirit of the thing.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I don't believe it.

Speaker: dyle
Dialogue: Well, I can't really blame you -- not now.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But I do believe it -- that's what I don't believe. So it's goodbye Alexander Dyle -- Welcome home Peter Joshua.

Dialogue: Sorry, the name's Adam Canfield.

Dialogue: The man's the same, even if the name isn't.

Dialogue: No -- he's not the same. Alexander Dyle was interested in clearing up his brother's death. Adam Canfield is a crook. And with all the advantages you've got -- brains, charm, education, a handsome face --

Dialogue: Oh, come on!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: -- there has to be a darn good reason for living the way you do. I want to know what it is.

Dialogue: It's simple. I like what I do -- I enjoy doing it. There aren't many men who love their work as much as I do. Look around some time.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Is there a Mrs. Canfield?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Yes, but --

Dialogue: Right. Now go eat your dinner.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I could eat a horse.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: I think that's what you ordered.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Don't you dare to be civil with me! All this time you were leading me on --

Dialogue: How was I leading you on?

Dialogue: All that marvelous rejection -- you knew I couldn't resist it. Now it turns out you were only interested in the money.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: That's right.

Dialogue: What would you like me to say -- that a pretty girl with an outrageous manner means more to an old pro like me than a quarter of a million dollars?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: No -- I guess not.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: It's a toss-up, I can tell you that.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Don't you know I'm having a tough time keeping my eyes off of you?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Oh, you should see your face.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: It's lovely.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm not hungry -- isn't it glorious?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Adam!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: It's all right -- look.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You don't look so bad in this light.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Why do you think I brought you here?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I thought maybe you wanted me to see the kind of work the competition was turning out.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Pretty good, huh? I taught them everything they do.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh? Did they do that sort of thing way back in your day?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: How do you think I got here?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Aren't you allowed to kiss back?

Dialogue: No. The doctor said it would be bad for my -- thermostat.

Dialogue: When you come on, you really come on.

Dialogue: Well -- come on.

Dialogue: I know why you're not taken -- no one can catch up with you.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Relax -- you're gaining.

Dialogue: Hey! Turn on the lights!

Dialogue: Hey! How do you stop this thing?

Dialogue: Three of them -- all in their pajamas! C'est ridicule! What is it, some new American fad?

Dialogue: And now your friend -- the one from Texas -- he has disappeared -- checked out -- pouf! into thin air! Where is he?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: grandpierre
Dialogue: Madame?

Dialogue: Tell me, Mr. Dyle -- where were you at three-thirty?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: In my room, asleep.

Dialogue: And you, Mrs. Lampert?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I was, too.

Dialogue: In Mr. Dyle's room?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: No -- in my room.

Dialogue: It stands to reason you are telling the truth -- for why would you invent such a ridiculous story?

Speaker: grandpierre
Dialogue: And if I were you, I would not stay in my pajamas. Good night.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: That wraps it up -- Tex has the money. Go back to bed -- I'll let you know when I've found him.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You're going to look for him -- now?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: If the police find him first they're not very likely to turn over a quarter of a million dollars to us, are they?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Adam --

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: There's no time -- I'll call you in the morning.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Yes?

Dialogue: Where are you, ol' buddy?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Open up.

Dialogue: I think we were wrong about Tex having the money.

Dialogue: Why?

Dialogue: I just heard from him -- he's still hungry. That means killing Gideon didn't get it for him -- so he's narrowed it down to us. You've got it.

Dialogue: I've looked, Adam -- you know I have --

Dialogue: Where's that airlines bag?

Dialogue: Lord, you're stubborn.

Dialogue: I sure am. Get it.

Dialogue: Charles must have had the money with him on the train, and Tex missed it.

Dialogue: But everyone and his Aunt Lilian's been through that bag. Somebody would have seen it.

Dialogue: Let's look anyway.

Dialogue: Lord, you're stubborn.

Dialogue: The letter --

Dialogue: I'll bet you don't really need those.

Dialogue: I love you, Adam.

Dialogue: Think, Reggie, you've got to think -- it may be what we're looking for.

Dialogue: Nonsense. We didn't steal it. There's no law against stealing stolen money.

Dialogue: Of course there is!

Dialogue: Five o'clock -- Thursday -- the Garden -- it's got to be something around here.

Dialogue: I know, but this is all we've got left.

Dialogue: Sorry, fella --

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: The letter.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Taxi! -- Taxi!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: All right -- where's the letter?

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: The letter? The letter ain't worth nuthin'.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: You know what I mean -- the envelope with the stamps. I want it.

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: You greenhorn -- you half-witted, thick-skulled, hare-brained, greenhorn! They wuz both too smart for us!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: First her husband, now her -- she hoodwinked you! She batted all them big eyes and you went 'n fell for it - like a egg from a tall chicken! Here!  You want? Here -- it's yours!

Speaker: tex
Dialogue: Look at you! Horn-swoggled by a purty face 'n all them sweet words! You killed all three of 'em for nothin'! You greenhorn! You block-headed jackass! You clod -- you booby -- you nincompoop -- !

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Sylvie -- ? What are you doing here?

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: Hello, Reggie -- I am waiting for Jean-Louis.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What's he up to?

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: He was so excited -- when he got the stamps you gave him this morning. He said he had never seen any like them.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm glad. But what's all this?

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: The stamp market, of course -- it is here every Thursday afternoon. This is where Jean-Louis trades his --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Good Lord! The stamps! Where is he? Sylvie -- we've got to find him!

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: What's the matter, chrie?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Those stamps -- they're worth a fortune!

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: A fortune! Hurry -- we've got to find him!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I don't see him.

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: We will separate -- you look over there.

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: Jean-Louis -- ?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Jean-Louis!

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: Jean-Louis!

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: Jean-Louis -- les timbrs -- o sont- ils?

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: Oh, zut!  Reggie -- Reggie -- !

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Jean-Louis -- thank heavens! Do you have -- !  What's that?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh no! What man, Jean-Louis --  where?

Speaker: sylvie
Dialogue: Vite, mon ange -- vite!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I don't blame him. Jean-Louis -- do you know where this Monsieur Flix lives?

Speaker: thophile
Dialogue: Oui, jeune homme?

Speaker: thophile
Dialogue: A Montmartre -- demande  Monsieur August au Bar des Artistes -- Place Blanche.

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: Entrez.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Monsieur Flix -- ?

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: I was expecting you. You are American too, of course.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: The man who bought them last week was American. I did not see him but I heard. I knew you would come.

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: Look at them, Madame.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm -- I'm sorry -- I don't know anything about stamps.

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: I know them as one knows his own face, even though I have never seen them. This yellow one -- a Swedish four shilling -- called 'De Gula

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: How much is it worth?

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: The money is unimportant.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm afraid it is important.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Do you mind if I sit down?  What about the blue one?

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: It is called 'The Hawaiian Blue' and there are only seven left. In 1894 the owner of one was murdered by a rival collector who was obsessed to own it.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What's its value today?

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: In human life? In greed? In suffering?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: In money.

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: Forty-five thousand.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: And the orange one -- what about the orange one?

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: A two-penny Mauritius -- issued in 1856. Not so rare as the others -- $30,000 perhaps.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: And the last one?

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: The best for the last -- le chef- d'oeuvre de la collection. The masterpiece. It is the most valuable stamp in the world. It is called 'The Gazette Guyanne.' It was printed by hand on colored paper in 1852 and marked with the initials of the printer.  Eh, bien -- I am not a thief. I knew there was some mistake. Take them.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You gave the boy quite a lot of stamps in return, Monsieur Flix -- are they for sale now?

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: Let me see. There are 350 European, 200 Asian, 175 American, 100 African and twelve Princess Grace commemorative -- which comes to nine francs fifty.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Here's ten.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Please keep it.

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: I am a tradesman, Madame, not a doorman. And don't forget these.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm -- I'm sorry.

Speaker: flix
Dialogue: No. For a few minutes they were mine -- that is enough.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Adam? Adam? It's me, Reggie -- !

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Dyle --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Mr. Bartholomew! Thank God you're there! Tex is dead, Mr. Bartholomew -- smothered -- and Adam did it -- he killed them all!

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Just a minute, Mrs. Lampert -- you'd better give that to me slowly. Who's Adam?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: The one who said he was Dyle's brother -- of course I'm sure -- Tex wrote the word 'Dyle' before he died. He's the murderer I tell you -- he's the only one left! You've got to do something!

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: Calm down, Mrs. Lampert -- please. Does he have the money?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: No, I do -- it was the stamps on that letter Charles had with him on the train. They were in plain sight all the time, but no one ever bothered looking at the envelope.

Speaker: bartholomew
Dialogue: The envelope -- imagine that.  Mrs. Lampert, listen to me -- you're not safe as long as you've got these stamps. Go to the Embassy right away -- wait, I'd better meet you halfway -- it's quicker. Now, let's see -- do you know the center garden at the Palais Royal? -- yes, by the colonnade -- as soon as you can get there. Hurry, Mrs. Lampert.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Yes, I'm leaving now -- goodbye.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- the stamps -- what've you done with --?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Where are you going? Wait!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- stop!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Why? So you can kill me too? Tex is dead, I've seen him! He said Dyle did it!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: I'm not Dyle -- you know that!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But Tex didn't -- he still thought -- !

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Don't be an idiot!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- ! I want those stamps!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Palais Royal -- vite!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Porte d'Italie, moi.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Mais c'est trs vite! On veut me teur!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Italie.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Billet, Monsieur.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: I don't want to go anywhere -- I'm only trying --

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Billet, Monsieur.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Come on -- please --

Speaker: train guard
Dialogue: Billet, Monsieur.

Speaker: train guard
Dialogue: Vous tes dans le premier classe, Monsieur.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: train guard
Dialogue: This car is for first class only -- you have a second-class ticket.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: But that's what they gave me.

Speaker: gendarme
Dialogue: Monsieur -- ?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Embassies -- embassies --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Shh.  American Embassy? Mr. Bartholomew's office, please -- Mr. Bartholomew's office --

Speaker: operator
Dialogue: Could you speak out, please? I can't quite hear you.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: No, I can't speak any louder -- Hamilton Bartholomew -- B as in -- uh -- Bartholomew -- that's right, and the rest as in Bartholomew!

Speaker: operator
Dialogue: I'm sorry, but Mr. Bartholomew has left for the day.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But someone's trying to kill me -- you've got to send word to him -- in the center garden of the Palais Royal, by the colonnade -- tell him I'm trapped in a phone booth, below him in the Mtro station. And my name's Lampert.

Speaker: operator
Dialogue: All right, Mrs. Lampert -- I'll see what I can do. Goodbye.

Speaker: operator
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Bartholomew? -- there was a call for you just now, Mr. Bartholomew -- it sounded quite urgent -- a Mrs. Lampert.

Speaker: real bartholomew
Dialogue: Lampert? I don't know any Mrs. Lampert -- trapped in a Mtro station? Who does she think I am, the C.I.A.? All right, you'd better call the French police.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- !

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- wait!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- why won't you listen?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm through listening to you!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: But I didn't kill anybody.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Then who did? You're the only one left.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- please believe me!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Mr. Bartholomew -- he's chasing me!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- stop! That's Carson Dyle!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Carson -- ?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: It's Carson Dyle, I tell you!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Tex recognized him -- that's why he said Dyle. If you give him those stamps, he'll kill you too!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Because he'd have to come out to get the stamps -- he knows he'd never make it.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: He's -- with the C.I.A. -- I've seen him at the Embassy.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Don't be a fool! He's Carson Dyle!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I don't know who anybody is any more!

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- listen to me!

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You lied to me so many times --

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- trust me once more -- please.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Can I really believe you this time, Adam?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: There's not a reason on earth why you should.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: All right, Adam.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: It won't get you the stamps, Dyle -- You'll have to come out to get them, and I'm not likely to miss at this range.

Speaker: carson
Dialogue: I'll give you five to make up your mind, Mrs. Lampert.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Wait, please! I need some time to think!

Speaker: carson
Dialogue: One --

Speaker: carson
Dialogue: -- four --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Adam -- please!

Speaker: carson
Dialogue: All right, Mrs. Lampert. The game's over. Come out of there.

Speaker: carson
Dialogue: I don't want to kill you, Mrs. Lampert -- but I will --

Speaker: carson
Dialogue: Did you hear me, Mrs. Lampert -- ?

Speaker: grandpierre
Dialogue: Mr. Dyle -- you are under arrest for the murders of Charles Lampert, Herman Scobie, Joseph Penthollow, Leopold Gideon, and whoever that is down there.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- you'd better tell him. He wouldn't dare hit a girl.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You didn't have to chase me so hard --

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Here, give it to me.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: That one's done -- start on this one.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I'm sorry I thought you were the murderer, Adam -- how did I know that he was as big a liar as you are?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: And that's all the gratitude I get for saving your hide.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: The truth, now -- was it my hide -- or the stamps?

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: What a terrible thing to say. How could you even think that?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: All right, prove it to me -- tell me to go to the Embassy first thing in the morning and turn in those stamps.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: I said, tell me to go to the --

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: I heard you, I heard you.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Then say it.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Reggie -- listen to me --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Never mind -- I'll go by myself.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: What makes you think they're even interested? It's only a quarter of a million -- it'll cost more than that to fix up their bookkeeping. As a taxpayer --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Who's a taxpayer? Crooks don't pay taxes.  Excuse me, soldier --

Speaker: marine
Dialogue: Marine, ma'am.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Forgive me. Whom would I see regarding the return of stolen Government money?

Speaker: marine
Dialogue: You might try the Treasury Department, ma'am -- Room 216, second floor, Mr. Cruikshank.

Speaker: adam
Dialogue: Do you mind if I wait out here? The sight of all that money being given away might make me break out.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Mr. Cruikshank, please -- my name is Lampert.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Mr. Cruikshank, a Miss --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Mrs.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: -- a Mrs. Lampert to see you -- yes sir.  Go right in.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Well, of all the mean, rotten, contemptible, crooked --

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: Crooked? I should think you'd be glad to find out I wasn't crooked.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You couldn't even be honest about being dishonest. Why didn't you say something?

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: We're not allowed to tell. May I have the stamps, please?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Wait a minute -- how did Carson Dyle get an office in here, anyway?

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: When did you see him -- what time, I mean?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Around one.

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: The lunch hour. He probably worked it out in advance. He found an office that was usually left open and just moved in for the time you were here.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Then how do I know this is your office?

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: Mrs. Foster -- send a memo to Bartholomew at Security recommending that --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Bartholomew?

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: -- recommending that all Embassy offices be locked during the lunch hour.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Starting with his own.

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: Okay, now -- hand over those stamps.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: What's your first name today?

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: Brian.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Brian Cruikshank -- it would serve me right if I got stuck with that one.

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: Who asked you to get stuck with any of them?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Is there a Mrs. Cruikshank?

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: But you're -- divorced?

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: My mother -- she lives in Detroit. Come on now -- give me those stamps.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Only if you can prove to me that you're really Brian Cruikshank.

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: How about if next week some time I put it on a marriage license -- that ought to --

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: Quit stalling -- I want to see some identification -- now!

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: I wouldn't lie on a thing like that -- I could go to jail.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You'd lie about anything.

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: Well, maybe we'd better forget about it, then.

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You can't prove it, can you? You're still trying to --  marriage license! Did you say -- ?

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: I didn't say anything. Will you give me those stamps?

Speaker: reggie
Dialogue: You did too say it -- I heard you. Oh, I love you Adam -- I mean Alex -- er, Peter -- Brian. I hope we have lots of boys -- we can name them all after you.

Speaker: cruikshank
Dialogue: Before we start on that, do you mind handing over the stamps?

Speaker: charade
Dialogue: Music by Henry Mancini, Words by Johnny Mercer  When we played our Charade we were like children posing, Playing at games, acting out names, guessing the parts we played.  Oh, what a hit we made. We came on next to closing Best on the bill, lovers until love left the masquerade.  Fate seemed to pull the strings, I turned and you were gone.  While from the darkened wings the music box played on.  Sad little serenade, song of my heart's composing, I hear it still, I always will, best on the bill Charade.
